title: GDPR Compliance Moat
context: The EU's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) was designed to protect individual privacy and give users control over their data. It succeeded at that. But it also created a massive compliance burden that large companies can absorb and small companies cannot. The regulation intended to constrain Big Tech inadvertently strengthened their position by raising the cost of competing with them. Google and Meta have armies of lawyers and compliance teams. A startup has a founder reading legal blogs at midnight.
hypothesis: GDPR protects user privacy and levels the playing field between big tech and smaller competitors.

effects.label: Compliance costs create barrier to entry
effects.impact: $1-5M for large companies, existential for startups

children.label: Legal review, DPO hiring, consent management, data mapping — fixed costs regardless of size
Startups spend 5-10% of budget on compliance vs 0.1% for Big Tech
Small ad-tech and analytics companies can't afford compliance — exit the market

effects.label: Big Tech consolidates data advantage
effects.impact: First-party data becomes more valuable as third-party data restricted

children.label: Google and Meta have first-party consent from billions of users
Smaller competitors relied on third-party data that GDPR restricts
Walled gardens strengthen — data stays inside the big platforms

effects.label: Cookie consent fatigue undermines the privacy goal
effects.impact: 95% of users click 'Accept All' without reading

children.label: Consent banners become annoying UX friction, not informed choice
Dark patterns in consent flows manipulate users into accepting
Users who care about privacy are exhausted by constant consent requests

effects.label: Innovation in privacy-respecting technology slows
effects.impact: Startups avoid EU market or delay EU launch

children.label: US startups launch EU-last due to compliance overhead
EU tech ecosystem grows slower than US counterpart

dontIf: You're designing regulation that imposes fixed costs regardless of company size
Your compliance framework doesn't account for the asymmetric burden on small companies
ifYouMust: Include small business exemptions or graduated compliance requirements
Fund open-source compliance tooling that reduces the cost for startups
Enforce against large companies first — they have the resources and the most data
Simplify consent mechanisms — the current cookie banner approach has failed

alternatives.name: Tiered regulation by data volume
alternatives.note: Heavier requirements for companies processing data at scale, lighter for small businesses

alternatives.name: Browser-level privacy controls
alternatives.note: Let browsers manage privacy preferences once, not per-site — eliminates consent fatigue

alternatives.name: Data dividend model
alternatives.note: Require companies to pay users for data use rather than just asking consent

sources.title: NBER: GDPR and the Lost Generation of Innovative Apps
sources.note: GDPR reduced new app entries by 33% in the EU, with disproportionate impact on small developers

sources.title: Oxford: The Impact of GDPR on Competition
sources.note: Analysis showing GDPR increased market concentration in digital advertising

sources.title: Reuters: Cookie Consent Fatigue Study
sources.note: Research showing the vast majority of users accept all cookies without reading consent notices

falsifiability: GDPR compliance costs are proportionally equal for large and small companies as a percentage of revenue
EU tech startup formation rates in data-intensive sectors match or exceed pre-GDPR levels
Big Tech's market share in EU digital advertising decreases after GDPR implementation

seo.description: GDPR costs startups 5-10% of revenue vs 0.1% for Big Tech. EU app creation dropped 33%. The regulation meant to constrain Big Tech became their competitive moat.
